The train to gains stalled in January as the stock market sold off sharply.
The Nasdaq gave away 1.74% in the first month of the year, while the S&P 500 took away 3.56%.
The Big Picture's market outlook turned to correction on Jan. 30. At this time, investors should sit on the sidelines until the selling storm is over.
Since the market sold off in the latter part of the month, the new buys list of top-performing funds the past three months still showed heavy buying of top-rated stocks.
Household names such as Facebook (FB), Under Armour (UA), Green Mountain Coffee (GMCR), Wynn (WYNN) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) were added by top funds in their latest reporting periods.
Health care stocks such as Actavis (ACT), Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), Biogen Idec (BIIB) and Align Technology (ALGN) have also performed well.
A handful of financial stocks were also being added by leading funds, including Envestnet (ENV), LPL Financial (LPLA) and CapitalSource (CSE).

IBD found 49 best-performing funds the past three months loaded Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) in their latest reporting periods, investing an estimated $119 million. The $10.5 billion Fidelity OTC Fund added shares as of its latest reporting period.

The Anaheim, Calif.-based drug firm focuses on treating patients with autoimmune and inflammatory disorders such as multiple sclerosis, spasms in infants with epilepsy, a kidney disorder called nephrotic syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.
Questcor has one superdrug, called Acthar, to treat all these ailments. Its earnings grew 96% and 73% the past two quarters on 64%-plus revenue growth.
The stock is working on the right side of a 24-week base. The current market slide has hardly made a dent in its formation. It's sitting at just 14% from its 52-week high of 75.
Sell Side

Leading fund managers have been taking profit from rail transportation company UnionPacific (UNP), with a net 57 funds selling the stock. The $139 billion Growth Fund of America has been trimming shares in its latest reporting period.

Big tech stocks such as NetApp (NTAP), Splunk (SPLK) and Check Point Software (CHKP) have also been sold by top-performing funds.The train to gains stalled in January as the stock market sold off sharply.The Nasdaq gave away 1.74% in the first month of the year, while the S&P 500 took away 3.56%.The Big Picture's market outlook turned to correction on Jan. 30. If there's one thing the Earth is not short of, it's sand. Anyone who's ever walked on a beach or driven across a desert can tell you that.
What you might not know is that not all sand is created equal.

That white, powdery stuff you toss in your kid's sandbox might be good for playing around in, but there's a reason you can get 50 pounds of it for a few bucks at your local hardware store. It's just regular, run-of-the-mill sand.
Frac sand, though, that's a different story. This is a durable, high-purity quartz sand with very round grains that, if it were human, would probably look down its nose at everyone else.

Emerge Energy Services (EMES) knows all about the high perch frac sand occupies in the sand world. The company, which operates as a limited partnership, is one of the leading miners and suppliers of frac sand used in the hydraulic fracturing process that produces oil and gas.
The rise of "fracking" in North American shale oil formations in recent years has led to an explosion in demand for frac sand. It has also driven strong sales and earnings gains at Emerge Energy.

Emerge operates two different businesses. Its sand subsidiary produces silica sand for the hydraulic fracturing of oil and gas wells. This side of the business operates sand facilities in New Auburn, Wis.; Barron County, Wis.; and Kosse, Texas.

The company also operates a fuel processing and distribution business. This unit mainly focuses on acquiring, re-refining and selling transportation mixture, or "transmix," which is a combination of refined products such as gasoline and diesel.

While the fuel business produces most of the revenue at Emerge, the much higher-margin frac sand business delivers the lion's share of net income. It is also a big reason Emerge's stock price has nearly tripled since the company's initial public offering last year.
Logistics Capabilities

"Emerge possesses a solid position within the frac sands market, particularly the coarse frac sands utilized in oily shale plays," JPMorgan analyst Jeremy Tonet noted following Emerge's 2013 third-quarter earnings report.
Demand for frac sand has more than tripled over the past five years amid a sharp rise in oil and gas production in the U.S. and Canada.

One advantage Emerge has over other sand producers is its logistics capabilities, Tonet says, particularly the rail connections it has to both the Canadian National Railway (CNI) and Union Pacific (UNP) rail lines at its Wisconsin frac sand facilities. These lines provide low-cost access to many U.S. and Canadian oil and gas shale plays.
"Given that production costs are one of the largest factors in competitive positioning within the frac sands industry, Emerge's low-cost operating structure is an important advantage," Tonet noted.

During the third quarter, Emerge's sand segment produced $47.4 million in revenue and $19.1 million in income. That compares to $222.8 million in revenue and $8.1 million in income from its fuel segment.
The reason for this wild discrepancy is that it costs a lot less to produce frac sand. When frac sand sales rise, Emerge's bottom line gets a huge boost.

Lately, that's what's been happening. Emerge's volume of sand sold during the third quarter more than doubled from the prior year to 734,000 tons. The gain was primarily due to its new Barron operation, which produced 344,000 tons during the quarter.

The additional capacity the Barron facility brings to the table has a couple of advantages, analysts say. One of them is "near-term organic growth opportunities," says Citigroup analyst John Tysseland noted.
In addition, he says, Emerge is "well positioned" to capitalize on the current industry shift to a preferred supplier market for oilfield logistics customers.
Big Competitors
"That will allow them to continue to win new business away from competitors based on their quality of sand and logistics attributes," Tysseland noted.
In addition to Emerge, other publicly traded companies that supply sand for oil and gas production include Hi-Crush Partners (HCLP), Carbo Ceramics (CRR) and U.S. Silica Holdings (SLCA).
These companies all specialize in slightly different areas.

Carbo produces ceramic proppant and resin-coated sand used in fracking. Hi-Crush supplies monocrystalline sand used as a proppant to improve the recovery rates of hydrocarbons from oil and natural gas wells. U.S. Silica mines and processes commercial silica used as oil and gas proppants and in industrial and specialty products.
Of the four, Emerge is the biggest, with 12-month trailing sales of $1.1 billion, though that's mainly due to its fuel business.

For the first three quarters of 2013 its sand segment posted about $114 million in sales, or 17% of the total. Overall revenue for the period rose 37% from the prior year to $627.2 million. Net income climbed 48% to $21.2 million.

The company is scheduled to report 2013 fourth-quarter results on March 13. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect earnings of 64 cents per unit. No prior-year per-unit earnings are available because Emerge wasn't publicly traded during the fourth quarter of 2012.
The company was formed in 2012 by Insight Equity, a private equity firm based in Southlake, Texas. Emerge went public last May at an opening price of $17. Its shares currently trade near 46.

Analysts expect full-year earnings of $3.04 per unit in 2014 and $3.09 in 2015.If there's one thing the Earth is not short of, it's sand. Shares of Norfolk Southern (NSC) rose Friday on a report that BNSF Railway Chairman Matt Rose said his company may enter the bidding for the struggling railroad. BNSF, which is controlled by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB), might step in to provide a competitive bid to Canadian Pacific Railway's (CP) $28 billion hostile offer for Norfolk Southern, Rose told Bloomberg…

Norfolk Southern (NSC) rejected an unsolicited $28 billion offer from smaller peer Canadian Pacific (CP), calling it "grossly inadequate."Norfolk Southern's board unanimously rejected the overture, saying that it would also face substantial regulatory risks and uncertainties.Canadian Pacific said late Friday that it was "disappointed" by the rejection but said he was "committed" to the Norfolk Southern offer."CP takes exception to the claims, misdirection and mischaracterization of its offer and the benefits such a combination would provide to customers, shareholders, the industry and the public," the rail operator said in a statement.Canadian Pacific said it will hold a press conference on Tuesday to discuss the offer, including concerns about regulator approval.CP CEO Hunter Harrison has tried to address such concerns. On Wednesday, he said that he didn't expect opposition from Warren Buffett, whose Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) owns BNSF Railway, because BNSF operates in the West, while Norfolk is in the East."I just can't image Mr. Buffett going to Washington and saying, 'Help me with these Canadians coming down in here and doing all these ugly things to us,'" Bloomberg reported Harrison saying at a Credit Suisse conference.Norfolk Southern shares closed down 1.1% in Friday stock market trading after tumbling as low as 86.59 intraday. Share edged higher in late Friday trading on the CP response. The stock has been working on the right side of an eight-month-long cup base.Canadian Pacific slid 4.6%. Berkshire Hathaway rose 2.9%.Canadian Pacific's proposal, which would combine the No. 2 and No. 3 railroads by market value, comes as railroads struggle amid dwindling shipments of coal and some other commodity products. IBD's 11-company Transportation-Rail group ranks a dismal 165 out of 197 industries.On Wednesday, CSX (CSX) Chief Financial Officer Frank Lonegro told investors at the Credit Suisse Global Industrials Conference in Palm Beach, Fla., "Domestic coal movements have declined more significantly in the fourth quarter than expected."In a statement, Lonegro said, "As a result, we now expect full-year EPS growth to be about 3%, which still includes an anticipated fourth-quarter property sale worth about five cents per share." Wall Street consensus was for 4% EPS growth in 2015.Bank of America Merrill Lynch on Friday cut its rating on CSX to neutral from buy and lowered its price target to 29 from 33, citing CSX's exposure to the coal market, though it also noted that CSX is working to improve operations and offset weakness in the coal business.BofA also lowered its ratings on Union Pacific (UNP), Kansas City Southern (KSU) and Genesee & Wyoming (GWR).CSX shares fell 0.9% Friday. So did Kansas City Southern. Genesee & Wyoming, which got a BofA/Merrill downgrade to underperform, skidded 5.6%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter @IBD_JDeTar and Facebook.

Rail operator Canadian Pacific (CP) on Wednesday made public the details of its bid for Norfolk Southern (NSC) — a 50/50 cash and stock deal Canadian said would create a safer, more efficient transcontinental railway — after Norfolk said late Tuesday it received the offer but reacted frostily to its terms.

Canadian Pacific, whose interest in buying Norfolk was reported last week, said Norfolk Southern shareholders would get $46.72 in cash and 0.348 share of the new company for every share of Norfolk Southern, making the offer worth around $28 billion. The deal was worth 97.72 a share near midday Wednesday. The new company would run both rail operators.

Canadian, which is Canada's No. 2 rail operator, said that by the time of the deal's closing, expected on Dec. 31, 2017, the new company would be worth $270.68 per share. Shareholders of Norfolk Southern, the eastern U.S.' No. 2 railway, would own 41% of the new company.
Canadian said the deal could bring over $1.8 billion in operating synergies annually in the coming years, as well as "substantial tax savings."

Those details, expressed in a letter dated Nov. 9 to Norfolk CEO James Squires from Canadian CEO Hunter Harrison, come after Norfolk on Tuesday said it would evaluate what it called "an unsolicited, low-premium, nonbinding, highly conditional indication of interest from Canadian Pacific" that represented "a premium of less than 10%" based on Tuesday's closing prices.
"Notably, any consolidation among Class I railroads in North America would face significant regulatory hurdles," Norfolk said.
Norfolk Southern has a market cap of around $27.7 billion, according to IBD data. Canadian Pacific has a market cap of nearly $23 billion.
Canadian Pacific climbed 5.8% to 146.58 on the stock market today. Norfolk Southern, which has been rising on deal talk, rose 7.1% to 93.10.

U.S. railroads have drawn more attention from regulators amid complaints of slower service and accidents in recent years. Railroads have also struggled as oil prices have sunk and demand for coal has waned.

Canadian Pacific in its letter to Norfolk said the deal would "deliver unsurpassed levels of safety," a sentiment it repeated through the letter. Canadian also said a merger with Norfolk would create "a larger, more diversified book of business less dependent on volatile commodities such as crude oil or thermal coal" and help thin out rail traffic in hubs like Chicago.
The potential buyout has raised speculation of further consolidation in the rail industry.
Union Pacific (UNP) rose 3.1%, Kansas City Southern (KSU) 4.2% and CSX Corp. (CSX) 4.5%.

Shares of Norfolk Southern (NSC), the No. 2 rail operator in the eastern U.S., hit their highest level since June on a report that Canadian Pacific Railway (CP) was considering buying the U.S. company.

Canadian Pacific, which seeks to build a transcontinental railway, has raised funds and has begun discussing a potential purchase with Norfolk Southern, sources told Bloomberg . But those discussions could still fall apart.

Shares of Norfolk Southern, which has a market cap value of more than $26 billion, jumped 12% in the stock market today. Canadian Pacific, Canada's No. 2 railroad operator, climbed 7.3%. CSX Corp. (CSX), which was the target of an unsuccessful takeover attempt in 2014 by Canadian Pacific, was up 2.9%.
Union Pacific (UNP) was up 0.1%, after rising as much as 3.6% earlier. Kansas City Southern (KSU) rose 2.7%, while Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB), the owner of BNSF, was down 2%.
The buyout talk comes as the rail sector has struggled recently with slowing demand for coal, the collapse of oil prices, and a cooling Chinese economy.

Norfolk Southern (NSC), the nation's second largest railroad by market cap, reported higher fourth-quarter earnings and revenue as it continues to expand its capacity and upgrade technology.
Earnings per share jumped 26% to $1.64, as revenue climbed 7% to $2.88 billion. Analysts expected EPS of $1.50 on revenue of $2.85 billion.
Shares were up about 5% in heavy volume in afternoon trading in the stock market today.
By commodities carried, chemicals rose 21% vs. the same quarter a year ago, while metals and construction gear were up 12%, autos 10% and agriculture products 9%. Only coal fell, dipping 2%.
"We're seeing the results of our investments in network capacity and technology," Norfolk Southern CEO Wick Moorman said in a statement.

He added that the operator of 20,000 miles of track in 22 Eastern states and the District of Columbia plans to invest $2.2 billion this year to upgrade operations as well as buy new locomotives and freight cars.

Wells Fargo analysts said in a client note, reported by Bloomberg News: "We think these results will be well received by investors as NSC was able to achieve record results despite head wind from coal." The bank rates the stock "market perform."
Rival Union Pacific (UNP), which reports Thursday, rose 1%. Kansas City Southern (KSU), which is slated to report Q4 earnings Friday, was up about 1%.

CSX (CSX) edged up fractionally. The Jacksonville, Fla. railroad's shares fell 7% last Thursday after it reported Q4 earnings and revenue that missed estimates and issued a conservative forecast for the first half of the year.

CSX (CSX) reports fourth-quarter earnings results Wednesday amid booming energy shipments and a gradual economic recovery, the first in a line of railroads scheduled to report over the next couple of weeks.
Consensus of 25 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is that CSX's earnings per share, excluding items, will rise about 8% to 43 cents. That would be the strongest growth in nearly two years.
Revenue is projected to climb 4% to just over $3 billion, matching last quarter's growth.
Norfolk Southern (NSC) is set to release results Jan. 22. Union Pacific (UNP) is slated to announce earnings Jan. 23.

CSX, which operates a 21,000-mile rail system in 23 states, said last Friday that it and its customers together developed 121 new or expanded facilities, with a combined $3 billion value, in 2013. That boosted the company's ability to serve customers amid rising demand from industry.
CSX has recently been growing like a young company as it expands in intermodal transportation, carrying trailers for semi trucks and containers for ships.
It's also expanded rapidly on rising shipments of crude oil recovered from rich shale fields using hydraulic fracturing technology.

"Growth in many sectors of the energy and chemicals markets as well as new and updated agricultural facilities generated much of the activity, which represents 151,000 carloads of potential annual business for CSX," the company said in last week's statement.

CSX may be affected this year by a finding last month from the federal Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, which said Bakken shale crude in North Dakota may be more flammable than oil from other areas.
It came after a BNSF train derailed in Casselton, N.D., in late December and sparked a fire that forced residents to temporarily evacuate. CSX and Union Pacific are the top carriers of Bakken crude.
CSX shares were down 1% in Monday afternoon trading on the stock market today, after touching an all-time high earlier.

Achieving optimal diversification in your portfolio takes more than just bonds and stocks, whether in the form of ETFs, mutual funds or individual securities.

There are many more asset classes and subsectors that can provide valuable diversification, such as real assets with exposure to various industries and commodities, in the U.S. as well as internationally.
Why diversify? Owning groups of assets that appreciate in value at different times can protect your portfolio from the violent downswings that single-asset classes have from time to time.
Northern Trust's FlexShares has collaborated with several index providers to give investors ETF choices for diversification. Among them:

 FlexShares Morningstar Global Upstream Resources Index Fund (GUNR) seeks to provide well-balanced, long-term exposure to natural resources in five sectors: energy, agriculture, precious and industrial metals, water and timber.
The first three sectors each constitute about 30% of assets, while the latter two have 5% each. The fund invests globally, with the U.S. accounting for 38%. It does not hedge its currency exposure.

Due to its periodic rebalancing and global exposure, "It's one of the more unique products in the space," said Shundrawn A. Thomas, global head of Northern Trust's ETFs. "It serves as a very good long-term hedge for inflation in a portfolio," he added.

Morningstar helped devise and maintains the index that the ETF tracks. The companies in the index derive at least 50% of their revenue from upstream activities. For oil firms, that would be the ownership of natural resources.

The $2.8 billion fund is not only the largest among FlexShares' ETFs, but also among its peers in the natural resources area. It has a 0.48% expense ratio and a 12-month yield of 2%. After a prolonged period of outperformance, the natural resources sector lagged the broad indexes in 2012 and 2013.

 FlexShares STOXX Global Broad Infrastructure Index Fund (NFRA) is one of Northern Trust's newer ETFs. Launched in October, it has $118 million in assets and an expense ratio of 0.47%. The ETF is thinly traded, with average daily volume about 33,000 shares.
It focuses on companies that have infrastructure ownership in the sectors of energy, transportation, utilities, communications and government outsourcing.
Thomas said that people in general are underinvested in this real-asset space. "When you look at infrastructure companies, they track really well to inflation," he said.

"The reason in part being when you think about some of the underlying investments, such as a road or a toll bridge, often the way that they earn their revenues are tied to inflation-pegged metrics, like CPI and the like," Thomas explained.
The fund invests 41% in U.S. equities, 11% in Canada, 10% in U.K., 10% in Japan and 6% in Germany.
Its biggest sector weighting is in energy at 31%, followed by communications at 28% and transportation at 27%. More than three-quarters of the fund is in large-cap stocks.

Transportation includes large-cap names such as Union Pacific (UNP), Canadian National Railway (CNI) and East Japan Railway. In the communication space, the fund invests in cell towers and data centers via companies such as AT&T (T), Verizon (VZ) and Vodafone Group (VOD).
 FlexShares Global Quality Real Estate Index Fund (GQRE) focuses on global real estate with the goal of providing inflation hedging and long-term capital growth.

The fund was launched in November and has only $17 million in assets. It is also very thinly traded, which may make it unsuitable for risk-averse investors. It tracks the Northern Trust Global Quality Real Estate Index.

Nearly half of the ETF is invested in U.S. companies such as Public Storage (PSA), Weyerhaeuser (WY), Vornado Realty Trust (VNO) and Host Hotels & Resorts (HST) .Achieving optimal diversification in your portfolio takes more than just bonds and stocks, whether in the form of ETFs, mutual funds or individual securities.There are many more asset classes and subsectors that can provide valuable diversification, such as real assets with exposure to various industries and commodities, in the U.S. as well as internationally.Why diversify? Stock futures shed Thursday's premarket gains and reversed to moderate losses after mixed reports on unemployment claims and Q3 GDP growth.

Dow futures dropped 57.2 points below fair market value, down from a 44-point advance an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures shed an 18-point gain and dropped 20.7 points. S&P 500 futures also reversed, trading down 6.7 points.

The stock market today received a boost from the Federal Reserve Wednesday that left the Nasdaq up 1.3% so far this week and the S&P 500 showing a 0.7% gain. Both indexes are working on what would be a fifth straight weekly advance.

More important for growth investors, small caps are having a strong week. The Russell 2000 surged 2.9% Wednesday — it's strongest session since Dec. 17, 2014. That lifted the small cap gauge clear of its 50-day moving average and put it ahead 1.1% for the week. Even so, the index remains well below its next test of resistance at its 200-day line.
The IBD 50 Index popped 1.6% on Wednesday and is easily outpacing the market with a 3.6% gain for the week.

A big day of economic news was off to a mixed start, with a preliminary estimate from the Commerce Department putting Q3 GDP growth at 1.5%, less than half of the 3.9% jump in Q2 and just below forecasts for a 1.7% increase. Price inflation also softened, with the GDP price index rising 1.2%, down from 2.1% in Q2 and a shade below views for a 1.4% advance.

Unemployment claims inched fractionally higher, to 260,000, in the week ended Oct. 24, the Labor Department reported. That was better than the uptick to 265,000 claims forecast by economists. The prior week's tally was 259,000 claims. The four-week moving average dipped to 259,250, its sixth straight decline.

Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Dennis Lockhart is scheduled to speak in Washington, D.C., at 9:10 a.m. ET. The National Association of Realtors reports September pending home sales data at 10 a.m.

Big oil companies got the earnings ball rolling, with Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA), Total (TOT) and ConocoPhillips (COP) all down 2% after reporting results. Oil prices backed off 1%, with West Texas Intermediate at $45.51 a barrel after surging more than 6% Wednesday.

Drug maker Pfizer (PFE) climbed 3% and Allergan (AGN) soared 11% on news reports that the two companies are exploring a possible merger. The Wall Street Journal quoted unnamed sources saying the talks were in early stages and details were unclear. Pfizer ended Wednesday up 4% for the week and less than 2% above a 34.79 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Among the premarket session's wilder moves, identity security firm Lifelock (LOCK) soared 40% on healthy Q3 results reported late Wednesday, along with news that it had settled a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit. Digital video camera maker GoPro (GPRO) dived 18% on weaker-than-forecast Q3 sales and earnings, also reported after Wednesday's close.

Among leading stocks, O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) jumped 3%, Tesoro (TSO) rose 2% and Ellie Mae (ELLI) was flat after their Q3 reports. O'Reilly ended Wednesday's session in buy range, less than 2% above a 258.25 buy point. Tesoro was 3% below a 105.64 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

NXP Semiconductor (NXPI) dived 13%. The Netherlands-based chip maker reported Q3 earnings up a stronger-than-expected 16%, but revenue rose less than 1% — weaker than estimates. Management expanded its stock buyback initiative to 20 million shares. NXP finished Wednesday just below its 10-week moving average, and has been working to climb the right side of a four-month consolidation.
Cavium (CAVM) took an 11% hit after reporting in-line Q3 earnings and revenue late Wednesday. The chip maker has been chopping out an uneven consolidation, and fighting to hold support, since June.

Shares of CSX (CSX), Union Pacific (UNP) and other railroads fell on a government report that said Bakken crude oil may be more flammable and dangerous to ship via rail than oil from other areas. That was a conclusion of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration on Thursday, following the derailment and fire of an oil-laden BNSF train in…

A $28 billion takeover pitch from Canadian Pacific Railway (CP) on Wednesday met with a straight-arm response from Norfolk Southern (NSC).A statement from Norfolk's management said that it would carefully evaluate what it called an "unsolicited, low-premium, nonbinding and highly conditional indication of interest."The pressure for rail consolidation comes as the industry reels from a steep fall-off in coal shipments to utilities and steel makers.Home construction and automotive markets have been bright spots, but agricultural goods — most notably fertilizer — have also been slow to rebound.The strongest element of demand, and a key factor in Canadian's interest in Norfolk, is rail-oil transport.Canadian Pacific officials set out goals of a 50% gain in revenue to more than $9 billion in 2018 vs. $6.79 billion this year.A third of the expected gains would come from oil shipments, they said.The targets depend on investment in western Canada to increase track speed limits and allow for heavier trains.Canadian also plans to expand multiple terminals in Alberta.In 2014, about 60% of Canadian Pacific's oil cargo was light crude produced from the Bakken shale in southern Saskatchewan.But company strategy calls for a turn toward safer, less volatile and more profitable-to-move tar sands crude from northern Alberta, which it said would soon account for two-thirds of Canadian Pacific's oil revenue.The company estimated that oil shipments would reach 200,000 carloads in 2015, up 67% over 2014 and 122% above 2013 levels.Norfolk Southern has also sharply increased its rail-oil shipments, moving 102,000 carloads of oil in 2014, up from 75,000 in 2013 and 22,000 in 2012.The company said that it hauled heavy crude from western Canada and light crude from North Dakota's Bakken fields.More critically, Norfolk operates a thicket of rail lines accessing the country's largest consumer markets and refineries from the Northeast down to the Gulf Coast.Canadian Pacific's lines connect Alberta's oil sands, U.S. and Canadian Bakken shale fields and Marcellus shale gas fields with Midwest refiners and West Coast export terminals, as well as the Toronto and Montreal markets.A combined Norfolk-Canadian railway would command 2015 revenue in the neighborhood of $17.4 billion, according to current estimates — still well below Union Pacific's (UNP) $22.1 billion.Any major rail merger faces significant regulatory hurdles, Norfolk warned.

CSX (CSX), Union Pacific (UNP) and other railroads say that financial momentum for U.S. railroads in the second half of the year has lost some steam.Falling prices and volumes for coal and gas, plus weakness in exports as China's economy contracts, have impacted shipments.Lower fuel costs for trains, plus the improving U.S. economic outlook, including strong housing and auto markets, have offset the impact somewhat.CSX Chief Sales and Marketing Officer Fredrik Eliasson, formerly the company's chief financial officer, said at Cowen's Global Transportation Conference in Boston that he expects the second half of the year to be challenging, given continuing headwinds in its coal market.As a result, CSX cut its full-year earnings growth outlook to the mid-single digits, down from its earlier projection of mid-to-high single-digit EPS growth for 2015, Eliasson said."While we continue to target flat earnings per share for the third quarter, achieving that estimate will be more challenging given the weaker than expected volumes," Eliasson said.Overall, the volume of goods carried is down about 2% in the current quarter compared to the same period a year ago, with both coal and merchandise markets tracking slightly below the company's original third-quarter forecast.Late Tuesday, CSX CEO Michael Ward announced that Oscar Munoz had resigned as president. Clarence Gooden, previously chief sales and marketing officer, was promoted to replace him amid a management shakeup.Eliasson was named chief sales and marketing officer. Frank Lonegro, former vice president of service design, replaced Eliasson as CFO, and Cindy Sanborn was named chief operating officer of CSX Transportation, moving over from her prior position as executive vice president of operations.CSX closed down 0.7% in Wednesday trading on the stock market today.Union Pacific Chief Financial Officer Rob Knight said at the Cowen conference that crude oil shipments for the No. 1 railroad by revenue spiked a few years ago, peaking at 163,000 carloads in 2013 and falling to just 49,000 for the first half of 2015.Offsetting that somewhat are higher grain and auto shipments, which are up from the same time last year. As Knight noted, IHS Global Insights forecasts that U.S. light vehicle sales will rise to 17.1 million vehicles this year from 16.4 million in 2014.Knight added that Union Pacific is expanding in Mexico and expects a record 956,000 carloads there this year, up from 882,000 in 2014.Union Pacific fell 1%. Its stock hit an all-time intraday high at 124.5 on Feb. 13 and has fallen steadily since then. It's trading well below its 50-day and 200-day averages.Norfolk Southern (NSC) Chief Marketing Officer Alan Shaw acknowledged near-term headwinds associated with declining commodity prices but said that its international volume continues to grow amid rising shipments from both East Coast and West Coast ports. Norfolk Southern was up fractionally.Smaller railroad Genesee & Wyoming (GWR) said Wednesday that global volume by carload for August rose 41.6% to 253,807 carloads after it bought London-based Freightliner in March.But same-railroad traffic, minus new cars and acquisitions, in August was 155,743 carloads, a drop of 13.1% or 23,441 carloads. North American traffic in August on a same-railroad basis fell 12.6% due in part to lower coal and metals shipments. Genesee & Wyoming fell 0.3%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter @IBD_JDeTar and Facebook.

Media and entertainment stocks sold off Thursday after Walt Disney (DIS) and Time Warner (TWX) were downgraded, as the sector continues to feel pressure from streaming services such as Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon's (AMZN) Amazon Prime.
Meanwhile, a pair of tech stocks — Micron Technology (MU) and Broadcom (BRCM) — also tumbled following downgrades.

Disney's stock price sank 6% to a 6-month low, slashing through its 200-day moving average and Time Warner fell 5% to a 10-month low. Both were downgraded by Bernstein early Thursday. The action came two days after Wells Fargo downgraded Disney, CBS (CBS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) .
The downgrades followed dismal Q2 earnings within the group and come amid fears that Netflix, Amazon and other streaming services will lead to subscriber losses and less cable ad revenue.
(Meanwhile, Netflix tumbled 7.8% and Amazon 3.2% on a rough market day.)
Micron shares declined 7.3% after it was downgraded to neutral from outperform by Robert W. Baird. Broadcom, which was downgraded to hold from buy by Argus, fell 3.1%.

Hormel Foods' (HRL) stock price rose 3.9% to a record 63.61 after Deutsche Bank upgraded it to buy from hold and raised its price target to 66 from 59. Shares rose 1.2% on Wednesday on better-than-expected earnings.
Alliance Data Systems (ADS) was upgraded from buy to hold by Stifel and given a $330 price target, but its stock price edged down 0.7%.
Toy manufacturers Hasbro (HAS) and Mattel (MAT) were initiated by Oppenheimer, with the former getting a perform rating and the latter getting an outperform. Hasbro fell 2.2% and Mattel rose 1.1%.

A pair of railroad stocks also saw analyst action from Macquarie Research, with Kansas City Southern (KSU) getting an upgrade to outperform and Union Pacific (UNP) getting a downgrade to neutral. Kansas City Southern (KSU) shares shot up Friday, roaring past their 50-day moving average after management said improvements in volumes in the second quarter look to be continuing.

The rail company's Q2 earnings per share fell 15% to $1.03, a penny above views, as lower fuel costs boosted profit. Revenue slid 10%, though, to $585.8 million as carloads slid 6%, undershooting Wall Street's $602.8 million target.
Sales declined in coal, fracking sand, metals and scrap. The lone exceptions were chemicals and petroleum, which rose 1%.
"As evidenced in the weekly industry carload data, there are still uncertainties in many of the primary markets served by rail," CEO David Starling said in a statement.
"However, KCS' average daily volumes increased each month throughout the second quarter, and the initial results from the first few weeks of July suggest the positive trend may be continuing."

Kansas City Southern shares were up nearly 7% in the stock market todayhttps://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ . After the rise, its stock was still 22% below a mid-November all-time high and it was traveling well below its 10-week line. It has a weak 37 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's been outperformed by 63% of all stocks.
The Kansas City, Mo.-based railroad serves 10 states in the Central and Southwest U.S. and runs lines in Mexico and Panama.

Other rail companies such as Union Pacific (UNP), Norfolk Southern (NSC), Canadian National Railway (CNI) and CSX (CSX) have been affected by lower energy shipments as coal declines and oil companies shutter rigs due to plunging gas prices.
Railroads have also faced unfavorable currency rates and weakening growth in China that curb exports to that country.

Mirroring Kansas City Southern's results, CSX earlier this week reported better-than-expected earnings, citing lower fuel costs, although revenue slid more than forecast as total volume slipped 1%. CSX shares edged up fractionally early Friday.
Union Pacific climbed 1.55%. Norfolk Southern rose 1%, and Canadian National Railway was up less than 1%.

Kansas City Southern (KSU) said it's reached an agreement to build a storage rail yard that it will lease to diversified firm Sasol Chemicals, which is building an $8.1 billion facility, including six chemical plants, in West Lake, La.The companies did not immediately provide financial terms.The project could help Kansas City Southern rebuild its revenue base, which along with profit growth has fallen due to weakness in the energy market. Like peers such as America's largest railroad Union Pacific (UNP), Norfolk Southern (NSC) and Canadian Pacific (CP), it's been hurt by low commodity prices in coal, oil, gas and steel.On May 14, Kansas City Southern withdrew its revenue and volume guidance and cut its capital spending target, citing uncertainty around energy markets and unfavorable currency rates. The railroad said at the time that its revenue was down by 50% and number of carloads had fallen nearly 40% from the same quarter a year ago.The railroad will build the storage-in-transit rail yard for Sasol and also replace and expand its existing rail car yard in nearby Mossville, La., to support Sasol's ethane cracking facility, which is expected to be completed by 2018.Ethane cracking is a process of converting ethane extracted from natural gas to create ethylene, a widely used chemical in the petrochemical industry.Kansas City Southern shares were down 0.8% to 93.37 in late morning trading in the stock market today, Monday. It closed at 90.02 on May 29, its lowest point since mid-January 2013. It has a poor 30 IBD Composite Rating, meaning 70% of stocks have performed better in recent quarters on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.The Transportation Rail Group is rated a near-worst 196 on IBD's list of 197 industries. Among others in the group, Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern were down 1.5% and Canadian Pacific skidded 2.3%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

As transportation stocks help lead the market, Union Pacific (UNP) shares are trading near new highs.The stock's sound performance is part of a sector move. The Dow transportation average is up more than 20% this year, and IBD's transportation sector was No. 4 out of 33 in Wednesday's edition.Union Pacific pays a quarterly dividend of 69 cents a share. That translates to an annualized yield of not quite 2%. The eight railroad companies that pay dividends have yields that range from 0.7% to 2.5%.The company raised the dividend most recently in January. It was the latest of several increases in recent years. The dividend has gone up more than 150% from the 27 cents a share it was paying three years ago.Earnings growth over the past three quarters ranged from 10% to 18%. That's moderately off from previous quarters and the company's three-year EPS growth rate of 28%. Its three-year Earnings Stability Factor is 5, near the best-possible score of 0 on a 0 to 99 scale.In the first-quarter report, slowing shipments for coal and grains weighed on results. But crude oil shipments more than doubled from the year-ago period, thanks to a boom in shale drilling. Auto and chemicals shipments also were strong in the quarter."Despite the fact that rail-based crude transportation costs five times more ($10—$15 per barrel), crude shippers are compelled to rely on rail-based transport," noted an industry analysis by Zacks Equity Research."This is due to the lack of pipeline infrastructural support in key oil and gas fields like Bakken Shale Formation in North Dakota and Montana, Eagle Ford Shale, Barnett Shale and Permian basin in Texas, the Gulf of Mexico and Alberta oil sand fields in Canada."

Domestic coal volumes for the year are expected to be "down at least 5%" due to low natural gas prices, said rail company CSX (CSX), while the strong dollar and overseas commodity prices weigh on global coal demand. Export coal volumes are seen falling to 30 million tons in 2015.

"While overall volume is tracking slightly below the levels in the second quarter of last year, service is improving steadily, and we remain on track to deliver second-quarter earnings per share that are flat to slightly up," said CFO Fredrik Eliasson in a statement. He had said in mid-May that Q2 volume was tracking slightly below expectations because of tough year-over-year comparisons.

Intermodal traffic and the company's construction sector are producing volume growth quarter-to-date, says CSX, and on-time originations and arrivals, dwell time and velocity "have all improved during the quarter."
The company still sees "mid-to-high single-digit range" per-share earnings growth for the year. Analysts expect slightly more than 6% growth to $2.04 a share in 2015.

CSX shares rose 0.3% to 34.19 in the stock market today. The stock has been bobbing around its 200-day line in recent sessions as it remains in an area of consolidation. CSX has an IBD Composite Rating of 61.
Norfolk Southern (NSC) shares fell 4 cents to 92.66. Canadian Pacific Railway (CP) shares rose 0.1%, while Union Pacific (UNP) stock rose 0.4%.
All are members of IBD's Transportation-Rail industry group, which ranks 195 out of 197 groups.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Kansas City Southern (KSU) shares dropped sharply early Thursday after the railroad withdrew its revenue and volume guidance and cut its capital spending target, citing uncertainty around energy-related markets, foreign exchange impacts and U.S. fuel prices.
The railroad said that in this quarter energy segment revenue is down by 50% and the number of carloads has fallen 38% from the same quarter a year ago.

"Key U.S. economic indicators have deteriorated since late '14," Chief Financial Officer Michael Upchurch said in a business update at the Bank of America Merrill Lynch 2015 Transportation Conference in Boston.
The company in March lowered its full-year 2015 guidance to low single-digit revenue growth, down from midsingle-digit growth earlier.

To cut costs in what it called a challenging environment, Kansas City Southern lowered its capital spending target for 2015 to $650 million to $670 million, down from its prior outlook of $700 million to $720 million.

Kansas City Southern operates in 11 states, Mexico and Panama. It earlier said it also was affected by the weak peso. Additionally, fracking sand and crude oil have been "negatively impacted by lower energy prices and spreads."

Service issues are in the mix. Although demand in automotive, intermodal and grain segments are strong, its volume is constrained because of "lack of crews in Mexico due to higher than expected attrition, on-going maintenance and capacity enhancement."
The railroad also announced a $500 million buyback to be funded with cash on hand or future financing.
Kansas City Southern shares gapped down as much as 4% before settling to a late morning drop of 2% at 95 in morning trading in the stock market today, Wednesday.
Its stock hit an all-time high at 126.49 Nov. 11 and fell 25% from that point to Thursday. It was on track for its fourth straight lower close and trading well below its 50-day and 200-day averages.

CSX (CSX) separately said it's seeing lower shipment volume but affirmed its earlier earnings guidance. Chief Financial Officer Fredrik Eliasson said CSX still expects Q2 earnings-per-share growth that's flat to slightly up vs. the same quarter last year, in line with estimates. CSX expects full-year EPS growth in the mid- to high single digit range, also meeting estimates.
CSX's earnings growth this year will be driven mainly by higher prices and productivity gains offsetting weak coal shipments, Eliasson said. Shares were down 0.4%.
Among other large railroads, Union Pacific (UNP), the largest U.S. railroad, was down fractionally.
Canadian National Railway (CNI) fell 1%.

A decade or so into the 20th century, the car industry operated like a poorly run bakery. It frantically tried new recipes and reacted to orders. Carmakers would blindly wait after auto shows for orders to flood in, then launch themselves into a spasm of assembly.
When the last order was filled, factory workers were idled until the next post-show orders.
The process of building the vehicles was just as inefficient.
Then came Walter Chrysler.
He would found Chrysler Corp., the firm that today rolls out Jeep, Dodge and Chrysler cars.
This was a correspondence-school electrical engineer who grew into a top manager, entrepreneur and auto-industry magnate.
Chrysler used information to optimize carmaking in a way that's recognized today as Big Data analysis.
Hence, Chrysler shifted into the fast lane, creating a market in lighter vehicles — sporting aluminum pistons — which were cheaper to build, then added novel features.

The first result of this strategy was the best-selling 1924 Chrysler Six, made by Maxwell-Chalmers. Chrysler had been hired by the firm to spark its operations. The next year, he bought Maxwell-Chalmers and renamed it Chrysler Corp.

Among the Six's innovations was an engine thermometer on the dashboard instead of out on the radiator cap. It was also the first passenger car with standard, four-wheel hydraulic brakes. Duesenberg was first to offer these brakes, but only as an option. Other U.S. carmakers used less dependable mechanical brakes, and only on the rear wheels.
The Slow Lane

Chrysler (1875-1940) hardly looked like a budding captain of industry in the first half of his life. He didn't enter the car arena until 1911, when he was 36. Ford was about that age when he got into cars, but he started years earlier.

Chrysler was born only 10 years after the end of the Civil War, and he felt the tough frontier. He wrote in his memoir, "Life of an American Workman," that he had to hide in his family's Kansas tornado cellar for fear of attack by Plains Indians.
As a teen, Chrysler followed his dad into the rail industry, starting as a mechanic, wrote Eugene Weiss in "Chrysler, Ford, Durant and Sloan: Founding Giants of the American Automotive Industry."

Chrysler demonstrated a natural aptitude for machinery. At age 18, he built a 28-inch replica of a locomotive that could be ridden on a track that he laid around the family's home, notes Charlie Hyde in "Riding the Roller Coaster: A History of the Chrysler Corporation."

Chrysler rose rapidly at each railroad he worked for, becoming a sought-after mechanic and manager. It helped that he had been mentored by a Union Pacific (UNP) veteran who taught him to trust only the information that Chrysler himself discovered.
By the turn of the century, the rail industry was mature, and companies competed by keeping costs low and operations efficient.
In order to outbid a competitor on construction of a new engine and still make a profit, executives had to know how much a finished model would cost. Margins were too close for estimates.
Arthur Darling, the master mechanic who'd schooled Chrysler, showed him how to maximize a locomotive's power by setting slide valves that controlled the intake and exhaust for each cylinder.

To that end, locomotive-factory workers inscribed marks on the valves as guides for railroad mechanics tuning an engine's performance, according to Hyde. But wear and tear changed the equipment enough over time to make the original markings irrelevant.

The problem was that using the factory's guide on older locomotives was easier and faster for a mechanic than taking new measurements. Darling gave Chrysler fresh advice: Get the most recent data for top efficiency.
Chrysler got the message — and became a strategic asset for every company that employed him.
His ambition — and sometimes quick temper — propelled him through dozens of jobs. "He could get impatient when people were slow to act," Hyde told IBD.
The author points to a particular day in 1909, when Chrysler was a superintendent at the Chicago Great Western Railroad, buying equipment on huge scales and leading 10,000 workers.

Once, after an overheated wheel bearing delayed a train by three minutes, Chrysler felt that his competence was questioned by the firm's new president. A shouting match ensued, and Chrysler quit. He quickly joined American Locomotive for his first manufacturing job, one that cemented his view on business: Success was in the numbers.
According to the Walter P. Chrysler Museum in Auburn Hills, Mich., he made sure American Locomotive executives knew "to a penny what it was costing us to drill a hole."

Two years later, an American Locomotive director who also sat on the board of General Motors (GM) recruited Chrysler as works manager within GM's Buick division. What he saw on the Flint, Mich., factory floor stunned him.
"Cars were made one at a time at fixed stations by skilled craftsmen — the same way high-quality carriages were," said Frank Rhodes, a Chrysler great-grandson.
Step On The Gas
Chrysler immediately ended the practice of sanding, painting and polishing car undercarriages.
That did more than save money. It also cut the time of assembling a chassis from four days to two.
Meanwhile, he rehabbed the carriage factory, replacing central posts with trusses to accommodate car construction.
Numbers tell the tale: He multiplied production from 20,000 vehicles in 1912 to 125,000 cars in 1916.
Soon after joining Buick, Chrysler made a point of watching finished vehicles leave the plant.
He noticed that Buick had a healthy quality-assurance process, with cars getting test drives. It was too healthy.

More cars were going out than coming back. So he instituted a log book for test cars, ending indefinite test drives, said Vincent Curcio, author of "Chrysler: The Life and Times of an Automotive Genius."
Also at Buick, Chrysler carried a cost notebook updated by the accounting department. He wanted to stay atop the numbers every day — and maintained that habit after starting Chrysler Corp. in 1925.

Chrysler stood apart. Ford Motor contracted with a manufacturing consultancy to improve its accounting. One of the recommendations, says the Henry Ford Museum, was to give managers cost information to help them make fast decisions. Yet the Ford titan dismissed the finding, saying the data were too complicated for employees.

Chrysler displayed unshakable confidence in decisions based on real-time data, notes Weiss. Once, when the board of directors doubted that a proposed model could be created as cheaply as Chrysler promised, he offered to take the difference between actual and estimated costs as his salary.

They took his word, and his numbers proved out. Not that Chrysler was lost in data. "He said an engineer's eyes, ears and hands were his best tools," and top engineers "don't take that lightly," said Curcio.
All For One

Then it was on to letting his hires do their job. "Ford sometimes couldn't get out of the way" of his executives sometimes, said Curcio, but not Chrysler, who groomed and managed them as independent assets who fed him information.

The result: success. "Ultimately, Chrysler did something in the auto industry that should not have worked," Curcio said. "He came late in the day to start Chrysler, and the company survived" to become one of the Big Three.
Many firms, not least of which were Ford (founded in 1903) and General Motors (1908), already had commanding leads in experience, output and revenue when Chrysler Corp. launched.
"Chrysler," said Rhodes, "built an engineering company" — as opposed to GM, which was built on the back of founder Billy Durant's strength in marketing.
Because of that, Rhodes said, "Chrysler always had some cool stuff in the pipeline" that could be pushed into production to address market conditions.

Chrysler, based in Auburn Hills, completed its fold into Italy's Fiat in 2014. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCAU) claims to be the world's seventh largest carmaker, with annual sales of $95 billion and a stock that has doubled since October.

Back in that first year of 1925, Chrysler produced 132,000 cars. By 1997, its last year as an independent firm, it was rolling out 2.9 million autos. FCA reported that its Chrysler, Dodge, Ram and Jeep brands shipped 2.02 million vehicles in calendar 2014.
Walter Chrysler's firm never was No. 1 in the market. Still, the carmaker's foundation was based on the collection and analysis of hard data followed by execution, and that has kept the brand alive.

After all, out of hundreds, only two other U.S. car companies have lasted this long.A decade or so into the 20th century, the car industry operated like a poorly run bakery. It frantically tried new recipes and reacted to orders. Carmakers would blindly wait after auto shows for orders to flood in, then launch themselves into a spasm of assembly.When the last order was filled, factory workers were idled until the next post-show orders.The process of building the vehicles was just as inefficient.Then came Walter Chrysler.He would found Chrysler Corp., the firm that today rolls out Jeep, Dodge and Chrysler cars.This was a correspondence-school electrical engineer who grew into a top manager, entrepreneur and auto-industry magnate.Chrysler used information to optimize carmaking in a way that's recognized today as Big Data analysis.Hence, Chrysler shifted into the fast lane, creating a market in lighter vehicles — sporting aluminum pistons — which were cheaper to build, then added novel features.The first result of this strategy was the best-selling 1924 Chrysler Six, made by Maxwell-Chalmers. Chrysler had been hired by the firm to spark its operations. The next year, he bought Maxwell-Chalmers and renamed it Chrysler Corp.Among the Six's innovations was an engine thermometer on the dashboard instead of out on the radiator cap. It was also the first passenger car with standard, four-wheel hydraulic brakes. Duesenberg was first to offer these brakes, but only as an option. Other U.S. carmakers used less dependable mechanical brakes, and only on the rear wheels.The Slow LaneChrysler (1875-1940) hardly looked like a budding captain of industry in the first half of his life. He didn't enter the car arena until 1911, when he was 36. Ford was about that age when he got into cars, but he started years earlier.Chrysler was born only 10 years after the end of the Civil War, and he felt the tough frontier. He wrote in his memoir, "Life of an American Workman," that he had to hide in his family's Kansas tornado cellar for fear of attack by Plains Indians.As a teen, Chrysler followed his dad into the rail industry, starting as a mechanic, wrote Eugene Weiss in "Chrysler, Ford, Durant and Sloan: Founding Giants of the American Automotive Industry."Chrysler demonstrated a natural aptitude for machinery. At age 18, he built a 28-inch replica of a locomotive that could be ridden on a track that he laid around the family's home, notes Charlie Hyde in "Riding the Roller Coaster: A History of the Chrysler Corporation."Chrysler rose rapidly at each railroad he worked for, becoming a sought-after mechanic and manager. It helped that he had been mentored by a Union Pacific (UNP) veteran who taught him to trust only the information that Chrysler himself discovered.By the turn of the century, the rail industry was mature, and companies competed by keeping costs low and operations efficient.In order to outbid a competitor on construction of a new engine and still make a profit, executives had to know how much a finished model would cost. Margins were too close for estimates.Arthur Darling, the master mechanic who'd schooled Chrysler, showed him how to maximize a locomotive's power by setting slide valves that controlled the intake and exhaust for each cylinder.To that end, locomotive-factory workers inscribed marks on the valves as guides for railroad mechanics tuning an engine's performance, according to Hyde. But wear and tear changed the equipment enough over time to make the original markings irrelevant.The problem was that using the factory's guide on older locomotives was easier and faster for a mechanic than taking new measurements. Darling gave Chrysler fresh advice: Get the most recent data for top efficiency.Chrysler got the message — and became a strategic asset for every company that employed him.His ambition — and sometimes quick temper — propelled him through dozens of jobs. "He could get impatient when people were slow to act," Hyde told IBD.The author points to a particular day in 1909, when Chrysler was a superintendent at the Chicago Great Western Railroad, buying equipment on huge scales and leading 10,000 workers.Once, after an overheated wheel bearing delayed a train by three minutes, Chrysler felt that his competence was questioned by the firm's new president. A shouting match ensued, and Chrysler quit. He quickly joined American Locomotive for his first manufacturing job, one that cemented his view on business: Success was in the numbers.According to the Walter P. Chrysler Museum in Auburn Hills, Mich., he made sure American Locomotive executives knew "to a penny what it was costing us to drill a hole."Two years later, an American Locomotive director who also sat on the board of General Motors (GM) recruited Chrysler as works manager within GM's Buick division. What he saw on the Flint, Mich., factory floor stunned him."Cars were made one at a time at fixed stations by skilled craftsmen — the same way high-quality carriages were," said Frank Rhodes, a Chrysler great-grandson.Step On The GasChrysler immediately ended the practice of sanding, painting and polishing car undercarriages.That did more than save money. It also cut the time of assembling a chassis from four days to two.Meanwhile, he rehabbed the carriage factory, replacing central posts with trusses to accommodate car construction.Numbers tell the tale: He multiplied production from 20,000 vehicles in 1912 to 125,000 cars in 1916.Soon after joining Buick, Chrysler made a point of watching finished vehicles leave the plant.He noticed that Buick had a healthy quality-assurance process, with cars getting test drives. It was too healthy.More cars were going out than coming back. So he instituted a log book for test cars, ending indefinite test drives, said Vincent Curcio, author of "Chrysler: The Life and Times of an Automotive Genius."Also at Buick, Chrysler carried a cost notebook updated by the accounting department. He wanted to stay atop the numbers every day — and maintained that habit after starting Chrysler Corp. in 1925.Chrysler stood apart. Ford Motor contracted with a manufacturing consultancy to improve its accounting. One of the recommendations, says the Henry Ford Museum, was to give managers cost information to help them make fast decisions. Yet the Ford titan dismissed the finding, saying the data were too complicated for employees.Chrysler displayed unshakable confidence in decisions based on real-time data, notes Weiss. Once, when the board of directors doubted that a proposed model could be created as cheaply as Chrysler promised, he offered to take the difference between actual and estimated costs as his salary.They took his word, and his numbers proved out. Not that Chrysler was lost in data. "He said an engineer's eyes, ears and hands were his best tools," and top engineers "don't take that lightly," said Curcio.All For OneThen it was on to letting his hires do their job. "Ford sometimes couldn't get out of the way" of his executives sometimes, said Curcio, but not Chrysler, who groomed and managed them as independent assets who fed him information.The result: success. "Ultimately, Chrysler did something in the auto industry that should not have worked," Curcio said. "He came late in the day to start Chrysler, and the company survived" to become one of the Big Three.Many firms, not least of which were Ford (founded in 1903) and General Motors (1908), already had commanding leads in experience, output and revenue when Chrysler Corp. launched."Chrysler," said Rhodes, "built an engineering company" — as opposed to GM, which was built on the back of founder Billy Durant's strength in marketing.Because of that, Rhodes said, "Chrysler always had some cool stuff in the pipeline" that could be pushed into production to address market conditions.Chrysler, based in Auburn Hills, completed its fold into Italy's Fiat in 2014. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCAU) claims to be the world's seventh largest carmaker, with annual sales of $95 billion and a stock that has doubled since October.Back in that first year of 1925, Chrysler produced 132,000 cars. By 1997, its last year as an independent firm, it was rolling out 2.9 million autos. FCA reported that its Chrysler, Dodge, Ram and Jeep brands shipped 2.02 million vehicles in calendar 2014.Walter Chrysler's firm never was No. 1 in the market. Still, the carmaker's foundation was based on the collection and analysis of hard data followed by execution, and that has kept the brand alive.After all, out of hundreds, only two other U.S. car companies have lasted this long.
JB Hunt Transport Services (JBHT) trucked past first-quarter earnings expectations, but the transportation logistics company fell short of sales forecasts.

Q1 earnings of 78 cents marked a 35.5% rise from the same quarter last year, the fourth straight quarter of accelerating earnings growth. Analysts had expected 72 cents a share. But revenue rose only 2.4% to $1.44 billion, below estimates for $1.54 billion.
Shares rose 2.2% to 89.63 in the stock market today. The stock is now in buy range to 89.92 after climbing out of a flat base with a 85.64 buy point in late February.
Intermodal load volume grew 6%, as overall segment revenue rose 1%. The West Coast ports slowdown limited eastbound intermodal traffic, said the company.

Dedicated Contract Services segment sales rose 7% on rate hikes and higher customer account activity. Integrated Capacity Solutions load grew 17% but revenue was lower per load, resulting in flat sales for the segment. Truck segment sales edged down 1% on lower revenue per tractor per week.

It's a big day for transportation. Norfolk Southern (NSC) tumbled in morning trade after the rail operator warned late Monday that profit would fall 14.5% to $1 a share on lower fuel surcharges and declining coal shipments. Norfolk fell more than 6% to 98.31, hitting a 10-month low.

Rival CSX (CSX) lost less than 1%. CSX reports earnings after the close. Kansas City Southern lost about 1% and industry giant Union Pacific (UNP) roughly 2%. Kansas City issued a profit warning in late March. Both it and Union Pacific will report next week.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

The stock market continued to trim losses in early afternoon trading, as the S&P 500 climbed above the break-even line.
The S&P 500 was up 0.2% after erasing a 0.4% decline. The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.4% advance, thanks largely to its energy and financial components.
But the Nasdaq lagged with a loss of 0.3%. Internet and chip stocks weighed on the composite.

Volume was tracking higher across the board. Breadth on the NYSE was much more positive than the indexes would suggest. Winners led losers by 12-to-7. On the Nasdaq, losers had a slight edge over winners.

Railroad stocks were some of the weakest in the stock market today after Norfolk Southern (NSC) tumbled more than 5% in heavy volume, thrashing a base it was forming. The rail company warned late Monday that profit would fall 14.5% to $1 a share. It blamed lower fuel surcharges and falling coal shipments.
Union Pacific (UNP) slid nearly 2% to a six-month low. The stock was one of the most heavily traded on the downside.
Several high-rated stocks were down in heavy trading, something the market had been avoiding.

Qorvo (QRVO) slid 4% in active trading, falling below its 50-day moving average. Not only was Tuesday's move a sign of weakness, but the stock has fallen 10% from its 78.15 buy point. That triggers a sell signal for the maker of wireless technology.

Zillow (Z) gave a weak outlook for 2015, saying that regulatory approval for its $2.5 billion acquisition of Trulia, which closed in February, took longer than expected. Shares were halted, then opened by gapping down sharply. The stock was already trending downward. Stock indexes were having trouble getting past the starting gate Friday afternoon. The Nasdaq gripped a 0.1% gain, while the S&P 500 was flat and the Dow Jones industrial average slouched 0.2%. Volume rose from the previous session's pace.E-signature and authentication products provider Vasco Data Security International (VDSI) surged 3% in volume about 50% above average. The small-cap stock first cleared a 28.27 buy point Wednesday and then dipped under the entry Thursday. Now it's back above the buy point.Vasco carries a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99, but the company's five-year earnings Stability Factor is 37 on a scale that runs from a calm 0 to a wild 99. The Composite Rating combines all five IBD ratings into a single number. A rating of 99 means the stock is in the top 1 percentile.Among big caps, eBay (EBAY) popped 1% in heavy volume as it made a new, 52-week high. The stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base May 29, clearing a 60.24 buy point. The cup-with-handle is a bullish pattern. Ebay was No. 19 in Tuesday's Big Cap 20, a computer-generated list of the best big caps by fundamentals and technicals.Other top price performers Friday afternoon included the super-regional banks. Several stocks in the group were threatening to cross buy points, including SunTrust Banks (STI), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) and BB&T (BBT). The fundamentals of the super regional banks, however, are spotty.Follow Paul Whitfield on Twitter: @IBD_PWhitfield.

Declining oil and coal shipments will play a big part when CSX (CSX) announces first-quarter earnings after the market close Tuesday, the first big railroad to report. Consensus is for the Jacksonville, Fla.-based company to report 45 cents in earnings per share for Q1, up 13% from a year ago, on a 1.2% uptick in revenue to $3.05 billion. Investors…

Kansas City Southern (KSU) shares dropped more than 7% as the railroad operator cut its full-year outlook to low single-digit revenue growth, down from mid-single-digit growth, on lower carload volumes and currency headwinds. Wall Street expects revenue growth of 5.6% for 2015.
The company, which has railroad investments in the U.S., Mexico and Panama, said it slashed guidance due to slower carload growth from the energy sector.
It also cited the peso's continued weakness and lower fuel surcharge revenues resulting from lower U.S. crude prices.
Kansas City Southern shares fell 7.5% to 107.07 in the stock market today.
It expects lower expenses to offset the negative impact of these factors, but lower carload volumes will cut operating income.

The company guided for first-quarter per-share earnings that are "flat to slightly higher" than Q1 2014 results. Analysts forecast 15.2% earnings growth to $1.21 a share on a 5.3% revenue rise to $639.4 million.
Coal revenues are expected to decline around 20%, said the company, due to lower natural gas prices.
Kansas City Southern reports Q1 earnings April 21.

Railroad stocks are down in early trading. Norfolk Southern (NSC) shares fell 1.6% to 108.68. Union Pacific (UNP) shares fell 2.8% to 114.21. Canadian National Railway (CNI) shares fell 1.5% to 67.32.

Morgan and Jacob Schiff of Kuhn, Loeb & Co. fought Harriman until they…

At 10, John Blair announced to his family, "I am going to get rich."That was an understatement.By the time he died at age 97, he was president of 16 railroad companies, the largest network headed by any individual in the world.His estate was valued at $70 million, equivalent to $2 billion now when inflation is factored in.Malcolm Gladwell, in "Outliers," calculates that Blair's fortune as a percentage of gross domestic product would be equal to $45.1 billion today, making him No. 47 on the list of the richest people who ever lived.John Insley Blair (1802-99) grew up poor on farms near Belvidere and New Hope, N.J., the fourth of 10 children of Scottish immigrants.His first entrepreneurial effort as a youngster was earning $1 for every skin of a wild animal he trapped.He left school and started working in a general store at 11.At 17, he opened his own store with his cousin in nearby Gravel Hill with their combined capital of $500 (worth $9,500 now).Blair bought his cousin out two years later and expanded to five retail locations, as well as four mills, by the time he was 28.As if he didn't have enough to do, he was named postmaster of Gravel Hill and remained in that position for 26 years. The town would change its name to Blairstown in 1839; he would continue to manage his growing business empire from there or from a private rail car, often traveling 40,000 miles a year.Bliss And BusinessIn 1826, he married Nancy Lock, the daughter of an American Revolution veteran who had been killed in the War of 1812. They would have two daughters, Emma and Aurelia, and two sons, Marcus and DeWitt. Emma would marry Charles Scribner, founder of the Scribner publishing house (now owned by Simon & Schuster).In 1889, Blair and DeWitt, along with DeWitt's son, Ledyard, who was still a senior at Princeton University, founded the brokerage Blair & Co. at 1 Wall Street. Ledyard would become a governor of the New York Stock Exchange.As Blair expanded his retail business, he put relatives in charge, then expanded into wholesaling goods to other stores. That push included sending wagons to New York City with produce; they returned filled with merchandise.In 1833, Blair made his first investment in iron mines at the Oxford (N.J.) Furnace, which had been operating since before the American Revolution. Success at Oxford led to Blair's establishing Lackawanna Coal & Mining in 1846.Then Blair really rolled. He invested in railroads in 1849, then in 1852 formed Delaware, Lackawanna & Western Railroad, largely to haul his mining materials to customers. He would remain one of its directors the rest of his life.As a Republican delegate in 1860, he attended the national convention in Chicago, where Abraham Lincoln was nominated to run for president. While there, Blair realized how important the city was as a center for railroads to the West.By this time, according to Edward O'Donnell's Great Courses audiovisual program "Turning Points in American History," 30,000 miles of rails had been completed, backed by $1 billion in investments — 30% of it from state and local government, and the rest largely in Wall Street bonds.But three-quarters of the tracks were in the industrialized North, not near Chicago. And by 1860, half the U.S. population was located west of the Appalachian Mountains, due to exhausted soil along the Atlantic seaboard.In 1862, the Homestead Act signed by Lincoln let anyone claim land by merely occupying and improving it. The same year, the president signed the bill to form the Union Pacific Railroad.The Transcontinental Railroad — stretching from the Missouri River to California — was coming.Forming a partnership with Rep. Oakes Ames of Massachusetts and Thomas Durant, a physician and financier in Iowa, Blair received a charter in 1862 to build the Union Pacific (UNP) track west from Omaha, Neb., to Promontory Summit, Utah, where it was joined in 1869 with the Central Pacific, which extended east from California.Going The DistanceBlair went on to construct the first railroad to run across Iowa from the Mississippi to the Missouri rivers. He also built a network through Wisconsin, Kansas, Nebraska, South Dakota, Missouri and Texas, earning him the title of the Railroad King of the West.In the process, he helped found 80 towns where his trains could stop, including Blair, Neb.He also started Iowa Railway Contracting and Belvidere National Bank, through which most of his other businesses made their transactions, demonstrating the financial power of integrated management of far-flung holdings.Charlotte Stewart of the Blair Society for Genealogical Research told IBD that records show Blair was proud that he "never put a dollar's worth of stock on the market to raise needed money, building every railroad for cash he advanced or raised among friends."His diversified investments allowed him to thrive despite the Panic of 1873, an economic depression that hit railroads hard, and the Panic of 1893, the sharpest downturn in U.S. history to that time."But his caution didn't make him immune to risk, of course, and sometimes he was even swindled, but he understood that this was the cost of doing business and moving toward long-term goals," said Greg Reid, organizer of the annual Secret Knock entrepreneurs' conference.Walter Borneman, author of "Iron Horses: America's Race to Bring the Railroads West," said: "Blair had his hand in many railroads and a number of other investments over the course of three-quarters of a century. But what really set in him apart from most 19th-century industrialists was his very early commitment to philanthropy. In addition to building and supporting 80 churches throughout his railroad empire, Blair gave generously to Princeton University, appreciating the value of the education that he never had. He served as a trustee for 33 years, funded the university's second oldest endowed chair, a professorship in geology, and gave money to build Blair Hall, still a campus landmark. When Rockefeller and Carnegie began to give money away, they were following his lead."By his death in 1899, Blair had given away $5 million, equal to $145 million now.

While falling oil prices obviously have had a negative impact on oil and gas stocks — eight of the nine lowest rated IBD industry groups are now in that sector — declining prices also have had a ripple effect on other industries: some for the better, others not so much.
Following are four other industries that have seen an immediate impact from lower prices at the wellhead and gasoline pump. Three are enjoying the trend, while one of them is not.

 Airlines: Considering that fuel is one of the biggest expenses in the airline industry, it's no surprise that falling gasoline prices have been a boon to companies that make their living in the air.
IBD's Transportation-Airline group is trading at record highs and ranks No. 2 among 197 industries tracked. That's up from No. 116 as recently as eight weeks ago.

Stocks that have set multiyear highs in recent days include pretty much every airline you can think of. These include large commercial carriers such as Delta Air Lines (DAL), American Airlines (AAL) and United Continental (UAL) as well as discount carriers Southwest Airlines (LUV), JetBlue Airways (JBLU) and Spirit Airlines (SAVE) and regional operations like Alaska Air Group (ALK) and Hawaiian Holdings (HA).
The top rated stocks in the group are Spirit and Southwest, which have IBD Composite Ratings of 99 and 97, respectively.

But airline stocks weren't winners on Tuesday morning. Spirit shares plunged 15.5% after reporting November traffic figures late Monday. United fell nearly 4% intraday after reporting a traffic dip. Other carriers also retreated.
 Truckers: Similar to airlines, freight trucking companies spend a lot of money on fuel. When fuel prices fall, costs go down and margins go up.
IBD's Transportation-Truck ranks No. 7 of all the industries tracked and has been steadily rising for the past eight weeks. The group touched a record high on Friday and is up 23% since Oct. 13.

Stocks that have set new highs in recent weeks include group leaders such as Old Dominion Freight Line (ODFL), which has an IBD Composite Rating of 99; Knight Transportation (KNX), which has a Composite Rating of 98; and Heartland Express (HTLD), which has a Composite Rating of 97.

 Auto parts retailers: When gas prices go down, people drive more. When they drive more, they put more wear and tear on the cars. When that happens, there's a rise in demand for replacement parts, maintenance and vehicle services.

That helps explain why IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Auto Parts group has been steadily rising up the group rankings the past few months. Though it ranks only No. 47, that's still up from 150th place 13 weeks ago. The group matched its record high on Monday.

"With gas prices at multiyear lows, we expect vehicle miles traveled to continue to grow, increasing demand for auto parts while providing relief to the low-income consumer," Sterne Agee analysts Ali Faghri and Michael Ward noted in a recent report.

O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) and Advance Auto Parts (AAP) are the top rated stocks in the group, with Composite Ratings of 97. AutoZone (AZO) shares rose more than 3% in the stock market today after the company beat earnings estimates Tuesday morning.

 Railroads: Here's a group that has been going in the wrong direction amid falling oil prices — mainly because rail operators have gotten a big chunk of their business in recent years from the North American oil and gas industry. Any threat to oil and gas producers will likely hurt railroad companies.
IBD's Transportation-Rail group ranks No. 141 — a big and swift drop from eight weeks ago, when it ranked No. 11. Shares of the group have declined 11% since setting a record high on Nov. 25.

You can still find at least one very good stock in the group, however. Union Pacific (UNP) has an IBD Composite Rating of 95 and regularly delivers double-digit EPS growth.
